cards.front: Qu'est-ce que l'épistémologie et pourquoi comprendre comment vous savez important que ce vous savez ?
cards.back: Épistémologie : branche philosophie questionne « Comment savez-vous ? ». Pas « Qu'est-ce que vrai ? » mais « Comment vérifier vrai ? ». Trois théories : (1) Correspondance : croyance vrai si correspond réalité (factuelle). (2) Cohérence : croyance vrai si cohérent avec autres croyances (logiquement). (3) Pragmatique : croyance vrai si fonctionne (utile). Implication : vous ne pouvez pas « connaître » sans fondation. Exemple : « Sais-tu changement climatique ? » Réponse : « Oui, car GIEC consensus + preuves data ». Ici : epist base = autorité scientifique + empirique evidence. Importance : sans epistem clarity, vous croyez arbitrairement. Cultiver : exiger toujours « Comment tu sais ? » à vous-même. Si répond « Je sais juste »→ probable blind spot.

cards.front: Comment le sophisme tu quoque (whataboutism) détourne argument et pourquoi c'est logiquement invalide ?
cards.back: Tu quoque (you too) : « Vous critiquez mon action, mais vous faites pire. » Sophisme : deux wrongs font pas right. Exemple : « Vous me dites arrêter pollution. Vous conduisez voiture polluante. » Non sequitur. Hypocrisy personne n'affecte validité argument. Si argument pollution = bad valide (basé evidence), hypocrisy n'annule pas. Whataboutism politique : « Gouvernement critique oppression authoritarian. Mais USA aussi oppresse ? » Faux : two oppression ≠ une justified. Détection : si réponse critique est « Mais vous aussi... » sans adresser argument original, tu quoque. Cela paralyse débat (tout le monde quelque faute → ninguém peut critiquer). Rejet : demander « But does that negate original point? ». Si non, continue addressing original argument.
cards.hint: Hypocrisy vs argument validity, deux wrongs

cards.front: Pourquoi l'utilitarisme (maximiser bonheur global) crée dilemmes éthiques insolubles ?
cards.back: Utilitarianisme : action moralement droite = maximise bonheur total, minimise souffrance. Semble sensé. Problèmes : (1) Calculation : comment calculer « bonheur total » ? Mesurable ? (2) Experimentation problematique : utilitarianisme justifie tuer innocent si sauve 10. Exemple : tuer poor person, donner organs à 10 rich = +9 bonheur net. Acceptable ? Non moralement. (3) Distribution : ne compte pas qui reçoit bonheur (tuer 1% population, rest très happy = utilitarianisme accepte). Critique : utilitarianisme ignores justice, droits individuels, dignité. Alternative : déontologie (some actions wrong intrinsiquement, indépendant outcomes).

cards.front: Comment la déontologie (éthique du devoir) diffère utilitarisme en cas moral difficile ?
cards.back: Déontologie : certaines actions intrinsèquement droites/mauvaises, indépendant outcomes. Exemple : mensonge = mauvais, même si ment sauve vie. Penser : si mensonge sometime accepté, quel principe arrête glissement (mensonge pour profit business, guerre) ? Meilleur : règle universelle (Kant) : action droite si voudriez universaliser. Donc : ne mentez pas car voulez-vous vrai accepte mensonge universelle ? Non → mensonge mauvais. Différence utilitarianisme : deontologie rejet tuer innocent même 10 sauvés (tuer intrinsèquement mal). Critique déontologie : trop rigide (ne mentez pas, période, même si sauve vie).

cards.front: Qu'est-ce que l'éthique des vertus et pourquoi elle focalise caractère au lieu règles ?
cards.back: Éthique des vertus (Aristote) : question n'est pas « Quelle action droite ? » mais « Quel caractère je veux développer ? » Vertus : courage, honnêteté, compassion, sagesse. Action droite = ce qu'un personne vertueux ferait. Différence autres : (1) Utilitarianisme cherche outcome optimal (quantifiée). (2) Déontologie cherche action selon règles. (3) Vertus cherche cultivir character pour prendre bonne decision. Implication : vous ne pouvez pas codifier tout (pas liste règles couvrir every situation). Vous développez jugement par practice. Exemple : courage ≠ fearlessness. Courage = peur + action anyway. Sage personne sait quand courageux approprié vs reckless. Apprentissage : imitation modèles (mentors), practice, reflection.

cards.front: Comment appliquer l'expérience de pensée du trolley à éthique réelle et ses limitations ?
cards.back: Trolley : trolley se dirige 5 personnes. Vous changez rail, tue 1. Moral ? Plupart disent oui (1 mieux 5). Variante : debout pont, poussez personne au rail, trolley s'arrête. Tuez 1, sauvez 5. Plupart rejet. Pourquoi différent ? Intuitif : action direct (push) semble murder, vs détourné (change rail) semble accident. Logiquement : utilitarianisme dit deux equivalent (1 vs 5 outcome même). Cela révèle : moral intuition ≠ logique pur. Limitation : trolley abstrait. Éthique réelle plus complexe (outcomes uncertain, multiple valeurs en jeu, relations matter). Mais trolley utile : clarifier intuitions morales, identifier précédents ethiques, force reasoning.

cards.front: Pourquoi le voile d'ignorance de Rawls crée priorité justice et limite inégalité ?
cards.back: Voile d'ignorance (Rawls) : expérience de pensée. Imaginez concevoir société, mais pas sais quelle position vous aurez (riche/pauvre, sain/malade, classe). Derrière ce voile : quelle société désiriez-vous ? Rawls : rationnellement, choisiriez égalité (car risque être au bottom). Inégalité acceptable si bénéfice poorest (trickle-down theory). Implication : critique inégalité extrême (société avec 1% ultra-riche, 90% poor = rationel personne refuse). Application : politique redistributive (taxe progressive) justifiée. Critique : voile idéalisé (impossible ignorer vraie position). Mais utile : clarifier que inégalité doit justifiée (bénéfice collectif), pas simplement « winners vs losers ».

cards.front: Qu'est-ce que le réductio ad absurdum et comment l'utiliser pour évaluer affirmations ?
cards.back: Reductio ad absurdum : prendre affirmation, suivre logiquement conclusions, montrer absurdité. Si conclusions absurde, affirmation probable fausse. Exemple : « Pas morale absolue. Donc torture innocents okay si culture accepte. » Absurde → premise fausse (soit moral absolu existe, ou système moral ne peut si permissive). Technique puissante : force thinker confront implicites conclusions. Mais attention : absurde dépend jugement. Une personne « absurde » autre « rationelle ». Exemple : « Pas liberté absolute. Donc gouvernement peut ban speech. » Reductio : « Gouvernement ban tous speech, oppression totale. Absurde. » Autre répond : « Oui, c'est risk, mais nécessaire ». Pas évident. Use reductio avec prudence : clarifier assumptions, pas simplement crier « absurde ».

cards.front: Comment la méthode socratique (questions) force clarification et expose contradictions ?
cards.back: Socrate : ne proclamait réponses, posait questions. Exemple : « Qu'est-ce que vertu ? » Interlocuteur répond. Socrate : « Donc vertu est courage ? Mais cowardice courageux situation ? » Force re-pense. Avantage : questionnement expose vague thinking. Si vous ne pouvez pas définir terme clearly, vous probablement pas comprends. Application réelle : débat productif = questions, pas assertions. Demander « Comment savez-vous ? ». Si vague, creuse. Dangereux : Socrate utilisé savoir déja, posait questions tendancieuses (sophisme). Faire honnêtement : questionnement sans agenda caché. But clarifier, pas piéger.

cards.front: Pourquoi le paradoxe de Sorites (tas) démontre limitation logique binaire et nuance réalité ?
cards.back: Sorites : 1 grain pas tas. 2 grains pas tas. 3... n grains = 1 000 000 grains = tas. Mais si chaque step « n grain pas tas » → « n+1 grain pas tas », logiquement jamais arrête → million pas tas. Absurde. Raison : logique binaire (est tas / pas tas) incompatible réalité graduée (spectre). Solution : fuzzy logic (grads, propriété pas all-or-nothing). Application réelle : « Est-il chauve ? » 1 cheveu pas chauve. 1 000 000 cheveux = chauve. In between = ? Logique binaire fails. Réalité : chauveté spectre, pas bivalent. Implication : langage humain imprécis. Cela crée désaccord (quand commence tas exactement ?). Accepter nuance = sortir debate sophisme.

cards.front: Comment le biais de confirmation affecte raisonnement critique même si vous pensez l'éviter ?
cards.back: Confirmation bias : chercher, interpréter evidence supportant croyances existantes. Même experts affectés. Docteur croyant patient X maladie Y → interprète tests confirmant Y, ignore tests contradictoires. Psychologue croyant thérapie Z marche → attribut improvement Z même if placebo. Vous pensez éviter ? Non probablement. Technique : activement chercher evidence contre vous. Si article critique votre croyance, force lire entièrement. Note points valides. Si ne trouve none = probable blinded. Test : pouvez-vous articeler argument opposite honnêtement ? Si simplement rejet sans understanding = bias probable.
cards.hint: Evidence seeking, interpretation bias, test honnête

cards.front: Pourquoi la corrélation ne signifie pas causalité et comment éviter cette erreur courante ?
cards.back: Corrélation : deux choses augmentent ensemble. Causalité : l'une cause l'autre. Corrélation ≠ causalité. Exemples : (1) Consommation glace augmente → noyades augmentent → ice cream cause drowning ? Non. Été cause both. (2) Dormir avec chaussures → reveille headaches → chaussures cause ? Non. Drunk people dormir vêtements → drunk cause headaches. Détection : demander « Mécanisme causal plausible ? ». Si absent ou alternative plausible → corrélation seule insufficient. Statistique : corrélation peut random (spurious correlation). Exemple : Nicolas Cage films vs swimming pool drowning deaths = 0.88 corrélation. Causalité ? Évidemment non. Caveat : corrélation peut suggestive (investigate further). Mais lonely corrélation ≠ proof causal.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce que le biais de survivance et pourquoi nous voyons seulement succès survivants ?
cards.back: Survivance bias : nous voyons succès (survivants) mais pas échecs (morts). Exemple : « Entrepreneur riche dit pas College needed → donc College inutile ». Survivor bias : vous voyez riche sans College (survivant), ignorez 1000 sans College morts economiquement. Data réelle : College correlated avec income +40% average. Autre : « My grand-mère fuma toute vie → smoking OK ». Survivor : voir grand-mère, ignorez millions morts cancer. Mortalité smoking = 50% raccourcir vie (énorme). Application : évaluant carrière, relationships, advice : cherchez aussi failed examples. Si seulement voyez succès, you probably biased. Correction : statistique, pas anecdote.
cards.hint: Invisible failures, selection bias, average vs outlier

cards.front: Comment l'effet Dunning-Kruger (confiance-incompétence) affecte jugement et humble progressif ?
cards.back: Dunning-Kruger : personnes incompétentes overestimate compétence. Pourquoi : ne sais assez pour savoir ce you don't know. Docteur amateur pense diagnose YouTube → confiance extrême (ne voit pas trous knowledge). Expert vrai → sait complexity → humble (« Je sais ce I don't know »). Courbe : confiance rise initiale (peu knowledge, big confidence), puis drops (expert realizes complexity), puis remonte (expertise vraie). Implication : votre confiance peut inversement proportional expertise. Cela explique pourquoi scientifiques prudents mais charlatans confident. Application : prudence si confiance extreme. « Je suis sûr » → risk potential Dunning-Kruger. Expert says « Je sais probable but not certain » → credible.

cards.front: Pourquoi la pensée de groupe (groupthink) peut dominer raisonnement critique même personnes intelligentes ?
cards.back: Groupthink : groupe cohésif suppress critique pour harmony. Exemple : réunion board, CEO propose idée. Tous pensent mauvais, silence. Peur rejet groupe > speaking truth. Résultat : bad decision, nobody objected. Raison : psychologie tribale (appartenance groupe > exactitude truth). Conditions : isolation groupe (no outside view), leader dominante, pression conformité. Dangers : corporate disasters (Enron), political errors (Iraq War), scientific mistakes (certain disciplines rejected valid ideas). Prévention : (1) Designate « devil's advocate » (force objection), (2) Externe feedback (outside expert), (3) Anonym voting (remove social pressure), (4) Encourage dissent (leader models vulnerability). Leader créant « safe space » pour disagree = better decision.

sampleIdeas.name: Logique formelle : pourquoi structure argument matière plus que contenu
sampleIdeas.textDescription: Logique formelle se préoccupe structure, pas contenu. Argument simple : (1) Tous A sont B. (2) X est A. (3) Donc X est B. Structure valide. Contenu peut être anything. Exemple 1 : Tous chats ont fourrure. Félix est chat. Félix a fourrure. Valide + vrai. Exemple 2 : Tous dragons volent. Boris est dragon. Boris vole. Valide mais irréaliste (dragons ?). Validité logique préserved. Cela montre : argument structure peut dépendre de contenu réalité. Deux aspects importants : (1) Validité logique : prémisse → conclusion suivent mathematically. (2) Solidité : prémisses vrais + logiquement valide = conclusion vraie. Vous devez check both : argument invalid content correct ≠ utile (conclusion fausse possible). Argument valid contenu faux ≠ utile (si prémisse fausse). Educé pensée critique demande examiner both structure et facts.

sampleIdeas.name: Les sophismes courants : arsenal pour débusquer mauvaise pensée
sampleIdeas.textDescription: Sophismes courants : ad hominem (attaque personne), homme de paille (déformation argument), pente glissante (causalité non-prouvée), faux dilemme (deux options seulement), appel à l'autorité (expertise non-appropriée), tu quoque (two wrongs). Vous les rencontrez daily. Débat politique : « Vous prétendez ambiente. Mais voiture polluante » = tu quoque. Médias populaires : « Docteur X dit Y. Croyez docteur X » = appel à l'autorité (docteur quel domaine ? criminaliste sur virology = zero credibilité). Débat personnel : « Si permit marijuana, société collapse » = pente glissante (Portugal légalisa, society ok). Reconnaître sophismes fortifie pensée. Technique : quand argument semble off, demander « Quelle sophisme c'est ? ». Si nommez, you've identified weakness. Débusquer sophismes n'annule pas argument (peut être valide), mais flagge need verify prémisses. Sophisme = red flag, not game-ender.

sampleIdeas.name: Comment évaluer si source crédible : expertise, bias, consensus
sampleIdeas.textDescription: Trois critères évaluer source : (1) Expertise. Auteur a formation/experience domaine ? Docteur parle santé, mais quel docteur ? Cardiologue peut moins credible psychiatrie. Vérifier credentials. (2) Absence bias. Auteur a conflit intérêt ? Chercheur payé tobacco industry parlant smoking-safety = obvious bias. Mais subtile biases aussi existent (professional pride, tribal allegiance). Vous ne pouvez jamais eliminate, mais recognizing important. (3) Consensus. Qu'est-ce que scientific consensus ? 97% climatologues acceptent changement anthropique = strong consensus. 1 dissenter n'annule pas 97. Cela ne signifie scientifique wrong (paradigm shifts happen), mais burden of proof on dissenter. Application : évaluant article, demander : (A) Auteur expert ? (B) Intérêt apparent ? (C) Align consensus ou outlier ? Si expert + no clear bias + align consensus = credible. Si tout opposé = sceptique justified.

sampleIdeas.name: Épistémologie pratique : comment savez-vous ce que pensez savoir
sampleIdeas.textDescription: Épistémologie : théorie knowledge. Question simple mais deep : « Comment savez-vous ? ». Répondez vous-même : « COVID dangereuse. Comment sais ? ». Réponse possible : « Gouvernement dit ». Epistemically faible (autorité peut error). Meilleur : « Data publique montre deaths augmentent ». Encore meilleur : « J'ai analyzed datos moi-même ». Même meilleur : « Je suis epidemiologist entraîné ». Chaque level = epistemic foundation meilleur. Application : quand quelqu'un dit quelque chose, exiger justification. « Je le sais juste » = red flag (possible bias confirmation sans examen). « C'est consensus scientifique » = credible (mais vérifier : vraiment consensus ?). « C'était ma expérience » = anecdotal (peut être survivor bias). Cultic leadership uses epistemic manipulation : « Ne questionnez pas, croyez ». Penser critique demande demander comment vous savez, accepter justifications insufficient.

sampleIdeas.name: Éthique appliquée : comment appliquer utilitarisme, déontologie, vertus à décisions réelles
sampleIdeas.textDescription: Trois cadres éthiques offrent perspectives différentes même situation. Exemple : vous trouvez portefeuille riche. Frameworks : (1) Utilitarianisme : rendre portefeuille maximise bonheur (owner + vous si recevez reward = net positive). (2) Déontologie : rendre obligatoire (ne pas voler, keeper, intrinsèquement droit). (3) Vertus : quelle vertueux personne fait ? (Honnêteté, intégrité, compassion = rendre). Tous trois guide rendre (outcome bon, action obligation, character droit). Mais différent situations divergent. Exemple 2 : you lying médecin pour sauver ami patient. Utilitarianisme : approverait (saving life = max bonheur). Déontologie : rejeté (mensonge intrinsèquement mal). Vertus : dépend (compassion suggest mensonge, honnêteté suggests révéler). Implication : no perfect cadre. Choisissez selon contexte. Utilisé ensemble = enrichit moral reasoning. Simplement utilitarianisme = peut justifier atrocités (sacrifice innocent). Simplement déontologie = peut être rigide (lie never ok). Simplement vertus = peut être vague (qui définit virtueux ?). Flexible moral reasoning = intégrer multiple frameworks.

sampleIdeas.name: Le biais de confirmation : pourquoi vous pensez rationnel mais vous n'êtes pas
sampleIdeas.textDescription: Confirmation bias : tendance inconsciente seeking, interpreting, remembering evidence supportant croyances existantes. Vous croyez thérapie Z fonctionn. Client améliore → credit thérapie. Client détériore → external factors (stress). Même évidence interprétée supporting croyance. Scientifiques sujet : croyant hypothesis X important → design expérience favorisant X, interprète ambiguous résultats X. Politique : supporter candidate Y → voir forces Y, weakness opposition. Opposant candidate Y → voir weakness Y, forces opposition. Même news consommed, opposite interpretations. Cela explique pourquoi débat impossible (both sides convinced right, ignoring counter-evidence). Solution : intellectuelle honêteté. Quand lire article critiquant croyance, force complétement lire. Note points valides (non faciles). Si ne trouve AUCUN points valides = probable confirmation bias. Exercice : articuler argument opposite votre croyance honnêtement. Si simplement rejet = bias probable.

name: Culture générale : repères essentiels
description: Repères de base en histoire, institutions et notions économiques pour une culture générale solide. Inclut civilisations non-occidentales, systèmes politiques, et dynamiques géopolitiques.

cards.front: Quelle date marque souvent le début de la Première Guerre mondiale ?
cards.back: 1914 (28 juin assassinat, puis déclarations de guerre en juillet-août 1914). Précédée de décennies de rivalités impériales, militarisme et systèmes d'alliances.

cards.front: En quelle année se termine la Seconde Guerre mondiale en Europe ?
cards.back: 1945. Le théâtre européen finit en mai 1945 ; le théâtre asiatique se termine en septembre 1945.

cards.front: En quelle année le mur de Berlin tombe-t-il ?
cards.back: 1989. Cet événement symbolise l'effondrement de l'influence soviétique en Europe de l'Est et le début de la fin de la Guerre froide.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce que les Lumières (XVIIe–XVIIIe) ?
cards.back: Un mouvement intellectuel valorisant la raison, la science et les droits individuels sur la tradition et l'autorité. Fondement des démocraties modernes et des révolutions libérales.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce que l'industrialisation ?
cards.back: La transformation d'une économie agraire vers une production mécanisée et à grande échelle. Commencée en Angleterre (années 1760), elle s'est propagée mondialement, transformant le travail, les villes et la société.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce qu'un État de droit ?
cards.back: Le principe selon lequel tous, y compris les dirigeants et institutions, sont soumis à la loi. Implique des tribunaux impartiaux, des règles transparentes, protection contre l'arbitraire.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce que la séparation des pouvoirs ?
cards.back: Répartir le gouvernement en branches législative, exécutive et judiciaire pour éviter la concentration du pouvoir. Chaque branche contrôle les autres (checks and balances).

cards.front: Qu'est-ce que le PIB ?
cards.back: Produit Intérieur Brut : la valeur monétaire totale des biens et services produits dans un pays sur une période donnée. Mesure courante de taille économique (non du bien-être).

cards.front: Qu'est-ce que l'inflation ?
cards.back: La hausse générale des prix réduisant le pouvoir d'achat. Mesurée par des indices ; peut résulter de demande excessive, augmentation de coûts, ou expansion monétaire.

cards.front: À quoi sert l'ONU ?
cards.back: Organisation fondée en 1945 visant à maintenir la paix, promouvoir la coopération internationale, protéger les droits humains et résoudre des enjeux transnationaux (épidémies, climat).

cards.front: À quoi sert l'Union européenne ?
cards.back: Union politique et économique (origine 1957 CEE) promouvant la paix, un marché unique, la libre circulation et des politiques coordonnées entre 27 États membres.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce qu'une source primaire ?
cards.back: Un document, objet ou témoignage original provenant de l'époque étudiée (lettres, lois, photos, journaux). Offre une preuve directe du passé.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce qu'une source secondaire ?
cards.back: Une analyse ou interprétation fondée sur des sources primaires, écrite par des historiens après les événements. Offre contexte et argumentation.

cards.front: Pourquoi distinguer chiffres absolus et pourcentages ?
cards.back: Parce que les pourcentages peuvent exagérer l'impact si la base est faible. Exemple : 50 % de 10 = 5, tandis que 10 % de 1000 = 100.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce que la Route de la Soie (historique) ?
cards.back: Un réseau de routes commerciales terrestres et maritimes (IIe siècle avant J.-C.–XVe siècle) reliant l'Asie de l'Est, l'Asie centrale, le Moyen-Orient et l'Europe. Facilitait échanges de biens (soie, épices), technologies (imprimerie, poudre) et idées (religions, philosophies).

cards.front: Qu'était l'Empire moghol ?
cards.back: Un grand empire islamique en Asie du Sud (1526–1857) dominant l'actuelle Inde et Pakistan. Connu pour synthèse culturelle, administration sophistiquée, architecture (Taj Mahal) et réseaux commerciaux étendus.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce que la Restauration Meiji ?
cards.back: La modernisation rapide du Japon (1868–1912) après l'abolition du féodalisme. Importation sélective de technologie, institutions et méthodes occidentales tout en préservant l'identité culturelle, devenant grande puissance.

cards.front: Qu'était l'âge d'or islamique ?
cards.back: Une période grossièrement du VIIIe au XIVe siècle durant laquelle les savants islamiques avancèrent les mathématiques, l'astronomie, la médecine, la philosophie et la littérature, préservant et étendant les connaissances classiques.

cards.front: Qu'était l'Empire du Mali ?
cards.back: Un grand empire ouest-africain (XIIIe–XVIIe siècles) contrôlant les routes commerciales transsahariennes d'or et de sel. Tombouctou était un centre intellectuel majeur avec une université.

cards.front: Qu'était l'Empire Songhai ?
cards.back: Un empire ouest-africain (1464–1591) succédant au Mali, dominant le commerce du fleuve Niger et maintenant des centres d'apprentissage islamique avant l'expansion portugaise.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce que la décolonisation ?
cards.back: Le processus par lequel les colonies ont gagné l'indépendance des puissances impériales, principalement 1945–1975. Résultat de mouvements nationalistes, affaiblissement des empires post-WWII, et droit international (Charte ONU).

cards.front: Qu'est-ce que l'impérialisme (XIXe–XXe) ?
cards.back: L'expansion de la puissance européenne (puis américaine) via contrôle militaire, économique et politique de territoires et peuples. Justifiée par idéologie raciste ('mission civilisatrice'), compétition de puissance.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce que le colonialisme ?
cards.back: L'établissement et maintien du contrôle politique, économique et culturel d'un groupe/nation sur un territoire autre. Impliquait extraction de ressources et subordination des populations locales.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce qu'une révolution (politique) ?
cards.back: Une transformation rapide et fondamentale du système politique d'une société, souvent accompagnée de violence. Exemples : Révolution américaine (1776), française (1789), russe (1917), chinoise (1949).

cards.front: Qu'est-ce que le capitalisme (définition basique) ?
cards.back: Système économique où les individus ou corporations privés possèdent les moyens de production, les forces du marché allouent les ressources et le profit motive l'activité.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce que le socialisme (définition basique) ?
cards.back: Idéologie économique privilégiant le contrôle collectif ou d'État des moyens de production, réduction des inégalités et satisfaction des besoins sur la profit.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce que le nationalisme (général) ?
cards.back: Une idéologie emphasisant la loyauté envers la nation, l'autodétermination nationale, et parfois la supériorité. Force motrice dans les mouvements d'indépendance et la politique moderne.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce que le 'soft power' ?
cards.back: L'influence obtenue via l'attrait culturel, la diplomatie, les institutions et les idées plutôt que la force militaire. Exemples : exportations culturelles américaines, attrait du modèle européen.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce qu'un traité international ?
cards.back: Accord formel entre deux ou plusieurs États codifiant obligations mutuelles, termes territoriaux, règles commerciales ou limites d'armement. Contraignant sous le droit international.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce que l'équilibre des puissances ?
cards.back: Système où plusieurs États maintiennent une force militaire/économique grossièrement égale pour prévenir la domination d'un seul. Central à la diplomatie européenne depuis 1648 (Traité de Westphalie).

cards.front: Qu'est-ce que le droit international ?
cards.back: Ensemble de règles et normes régissant les relations entre États : traités, conventions, coutumes reconnues. Exécution problématique : faible sanction de violations, souvent dominé par grandes puissances.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce qu'une dictature ?
cards.back: Régime autoritaire où un individu ou petit groupe détient le pouvoir absolu sans consentement démocratique, souvent imposé par force. Limites légales inexistantes ou fictives.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce qu'une oligarchie ?
cards.back: Système de pouvoir où un petit groupe (hommes riches, familles, corporations) gouverne dans leurs propres intérêts. Peut être formellement démocratique mais contrôlé par élites.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce qu'une démocratie libérale ?
cards.back: Système combinant élections démocratiques, séparation des pouvoirs, droits individuels protégés constitutionnellement et État de droit. Typage occidental dominant mais dont principes se retrouvent dans variantes globales.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce qu'un empire ?
cards.back: Un ensemble de territoires et peuples sous contrôle d'une puissance centrale. Les empires varient : territoires contigus (Romain) ou éparpillés (Britannique). Généralement marqués par extraction de ressources et domination culturelle.

cards.front: Qu'est-ce que le nationalisme économique ?
cards.back: Politique privilégiant l'économie nationale : protectionnisme (tarifs, barrières), réduction de l'importation, autosuffisance. Contraste avec libre-échange. Débat : peut protéger l'emploi mais augmente coûts consommateurs.

sampleIdeas.name: Route de la Soie : bien plus que du commerce
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
La Route de la Soie (IIe siècle avant J.-C.–XVe siècle) n'était pas une route unique mais un vaste réseau reliant Chine, Asie centrale, Perse, Inde et Europe.

Le commerce de marchandises (soie, épices, céramiques, métaux) était crucial. Mais aussi important : les technologies ont voyagé (imprimerie, poudre à canon vers l'ouest ; technologies agricoles vers l'est), les religions se sont propagées (bouddhisme, islam), les styles architecturaux et artistiques se sont mélangés.

Étudier la Route de la Soie révèle que la mondialisation est ancienne, non moderne. Elle montre aussi comment les régions intermédiaires (Asie centrale, Perse) étaient des centres de richesse et de culture, pas seulement des périphéries.

Utilisez la Route de la Soie pour comprendre : le commerce crée l'échange culturel ; la distance est relative ; les régions non-occidentales étaient des centres dynamiques.

sampleIdeas.name: Empires africains : Mali et Songhai
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
L'Afrique de l'Ouest, XIIIe–XVIe siècles, abritait des États puissants et organisés contrôlant le commerce transsaharien d'or et de sel.

Mali (1230–1600) et Songhai (1464–1591) n'étaient pas des sociétés tribales isolées mais des empires avec systèmes administratifs, armées et centres d'apprentissage islamique. Tombouctou avait une université.

Ils ont été perturbés en partie par l'exploration portugaise et la traite d'esclaves, illustrant comment les pressions externes ont altéré les trajectoires africaines.

Idée reçue clé : l'Afrique n'avait pas 'd'histoire' avant le contact européen. En réalité, l'Afrique précoloniale avait des États complexes, des réseaux commerciaux et des traditions intellectuelles. Apprendre ceci corrige un biais eurocentriste profond.

sampleIdeas.name: L'Empire moghol : science islamique et gouvernance en Asie
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
L'Empire moghol (1526–1857) a gouverné le Sous-continent indien avec un système administratif multiculturel et sophistiqué.

Les Moghols ont synthétisé les cultures persane, islamique et indienne. Ils ont patronné l'architecture (Taj Mahal, Fort Rouge de Delhi), les savants et ont construit des réseaux commerciaux s'étendant en Europe et Asie du Sud-Est.

Leur système administratif a influencé la gouvernance coloniale britannique ultérieure.

Importance : cela remet en question l'hypothèse que l'Asie était statique avant le contact occidental. Les Moghols montrent des empires prospères, des échanges intellectuels et une statecraft complexe rivalisant l'Europe. Comprendre ceci corrige les narratifs eurocentriques des manuels.

sampleIdeas.name: Restauration Meiji : modernisation sans occidentalisation
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Le Japon, post-1868, faisait face à un choix : résister ou s'adapter à l'Occident ? Les Meiji ont choisi l'adoption stratégique.

Ils ont importé chemins de fer, aciéries, systèmes bureaucratiques et technologie militaire. Mais ils ont préservé les traditions shinto, l'éducation en langue japonaise et les valeurs hiérarchiques.

Parfois 1910, le Japon était une grande puissance—non par occidentalisation complète mais par emprunt contrôlé et sélectif.

Leçon clé : la modernisation ne requiert pas l'occidentalisation. Les sociétés non-occidentales peuvent innover tout en maintenant l'identité. Ceci rompt le faux binaire de 'traditionnel vs moderne'. Montre aussi comment la transformation rapide est possible avec une décision centralisée et une cohérence culturelle.

sampleIdeas.name: Décolonisation : la fin de l'empire
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Entre 1945–1975, la plupart des territoires coloniaux ont gagné l'indépendance. Ceci n'était pas inévitable : les empires ont combattu pour conserver le pouvoir (Indochine française, Algérie ; Kenya britannique). Cela a réussi via mouvements nationalistes, droit international (Charte ONU) et l'affaiblissement post-WWII des puissances européennes.

La décolonisation a reconfiguré le monde : nouvelles nations ont rejoint l'ONU, la Guerre froide a compétitionné pour leur allégeance, et beaucoup ont lutté avec des frontières imposées et des économies extractivistes.

Comprendre la décolonisation est clé à la géopolitique moderne. Les conflits actuels reflètent souvent l'héritage colonial (frontières artificielles, extraction de ressources, méfiance envers les institutions). Cela montre aussi comment les shifts de pouvoir—les empires, autrefois permanents, se sont effondrés rapidement.

sampleIdeas.name: Impérialisme et ses effets durables
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
XIXe et début XXe siècles : les puissances européennes ont divisé l'Afrique, l'Asie et parties des Amériques via la force militaire, revendications légales et domination économique.

L'impérialisme a été justifié par idéologie raciste ('mission civilisatrice', darwinisme social) et politique de puissance compétitive.

Effets : extraction de ressources ; création de frontières artificielles ; imposition de langues et religions ; disruption des économies locales ; semis de ressentiment nationaliste.

L'inégalité mondiale actuelle, zones de conflit (Moyen-Orient, Afrique) et domination linguistique/culturelle (anglais, français) tracent partiellement à l'impérialisme. Reconnaître ce schéma aide à expliquer la géopolitique moderne et réduit les hypothèses eurocentriques sur les hiérarchies 'naturelles'.

sampleIdeas.name: Lumières et démocratie moderne
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
XVIIe–XVIIIe siècles : les penseurs européens (Locke, Montesquieu, Rousseau) ont soutenu que l'autorité politique vient de la raison, des droits naturels et du peuple—non du droit divin ou de la tradition.

Ces idées ont justifié les révolutions (américaine 1776, française 1789) et façonné les constitutions modernes, séparation des pouvoirs et concepts de droits universels.

Mais nuance : les penseurs des Lumières étaient produits de leur époque. Beaucoup soutenaient l'esclavage, le colonialisme et les hiérarchies de genre. Aussi, des idées similaires se sont développées indépendamment dans des contextes non-occidentaux.

Leçon : tracez les racines intellectuelles de la politique moderne ; reconnaissez les contributions des Lumières tout en critiquant leurs limites ; évitez d'assumer que les idées occidentales sont supérieures—comparez avec la jurisprudence islamique, la philosophie chinoise, etc.

sampleIdeas.name: Capitalisme vs socialisme : débat persistant
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Le capitalisme privilégie la propriété privée et les marchés. Le socialisme privilégie la propriété collective et la redistribution.

En réalité : la plupart des économies modernes sont mixtes. Les États-Unis (capitaliste) ont filets de sécurité sociale ; la Suède (social-démocrate) a marchés et entreprises privées.

Debat : capitalisme crée innovation et efficacité, mais peut accumuler richesse et causer exploitations. Socialisme veut l'équité, mais historiquement a souvent eu déficits de performance ou autoritarisme.

Nuance : évitez les étiquettes binaires. Demandez : quels services sont privatisés vs publics, comment la richesse est distribuée, qui prend les décisions économiques ? Cela révèle les réalités complexes des systèmes économiques modernes.

name: Computer Science Foundations (CS50)
description: Computational thinking, Scratch programming, and number representation. Week 0 concepts from CS50 Harvard.

cards.front: What is computer science at its core?
cards.back: The study of problem-solving using computation—translating problems into instructions that computers can follow. It's about being systematic and logical, not just writing code.

cards.front: Why is computational thinking valuable even if you never code again?
cards.back: Computational thinking teaches decomposition (breaking large problems into parts), pattern recognition, abstraction (ignoring irrelevant details), and algorithm design. These skills apply to any discipline—science, business, art.

cards.front: What is a sprite in Scratch?
cards.back: A sprite is a character or object that you can program. In Scratch, you give sprites instructions via code blocks. For example, a sprite can move, change costumes, and respond to clicks or keyboard input.

cards.front: How do loops make programming more efficient than repeating code?
cards.back: Instead of writing the same instruction 100 times, a loop (like 'repeat 100') executes that block automatically. This saves time, reduces mistakes, and makes code easier to change later.

cards.front: Why do events matter in interactive programs like games?
cards.back: Events (like key presses or clicks) let programs respond to the user in real-time. Without events, a game couldn't react when the player tries to jump or attack.

cards.front: What is the difference between a condition and a loop in Scratch?
cards.back: A condition (if/else) makes a decision once: 'if touching mouse-pointer, then say hello'. A loop repeats: 'repeat 10 times, move 10 steps'. Conditions check what is true; loops repeat actions.

cards.front: What does a function do in Scratch, and why is it useful?
cards.back: A function (custom block) lets you group code under a name and reuse it. Instead of repeating a complex sequence, you call it by name. This reduces errors and makes code clearer.

cards.front: How does a variable store information in Scratch?
cards.back: A variable is a named container holding a value (number, text, or true/false). You can change it, read it, and use it in decisions. For example, a 'score' variable tracks the game score.

cards.front: What is abstraction and how does Scratch teach it?
cards.back: Abstraction hides complex details behind simple labels. In Scratch, a 'move' block abstracts away all the math and graphics; you don't need to know how the computer redraws the sprite. You just say 'move 10 steps'.

cards.front: Why do programmers say 'garbage in, garbage out'?
cards.back: If your algorithm or input data is flawed, the output will be wrong no matter how well you code. For example, a search algorithm is useless on unsorted data if binary search requires sorting. Understand your inputs first.

cards.front: What is a bit and why do computers use binary?
cards.back: A bit is 0 or 1, the smallest unit of data. Computers use binary because physical switches are easy: on (1) or off (0). All data—text, images, sound—is ultimately stored as 1s and 0s.

cards.front: What does a byte represent and why group 8 bits?
cards.back: A byte is 8 bits. Eight bits can represent 256 different values (0–255), which is large enough for many purposes (like ASCII characters). It became a standard unit because it balances granularity and efficiency.

cards.front: How does binary numbering work? (e.g., what is 1010 in decimal?)
cards.back: Binary is base-2. Each position represents a power of 2: rightmost is 2^0 (1), next is 2^1 (2), then 2^2 (4), 2^3 (8). So 1010 = 1×8 + 0×4 + 1×2 + 0×1 = 10 in decimal.

cards.front: What is ASCII and what problem does it solve?
cards.back: ASCII is a standard mapping of characters to numbers: 'A' = 65, 'a' = 97, '0' = 48. Without a standard, different computers couldn't share text. ASCII solved that by making a universal key.

cards.front: Why is Unicode more useful than ASCII?
cards.back: ASCII only handles 128 characters (English letters, digits, punctuation). Unicode handles millions, supporting every language, emoji, and symbol. As computing became global, Unicode became necessary.

cards.front: What does RGB represent in color graphics?
cards.back: RGB stands for Red, Green, Blue. Each color channel has a value 0–255. Combined, they create any color on screen. For example, (255, 0, 0) is pure red; (255, 255, 255) is white; (0, 0, 0) is black.

cards.front: Why is decomposition the first step in problem-solving?
cards.back: Large problems are overwhelming. Decomposing breaks them into smaller, manageable pieces. For example, 'make a game' becomes 'draw sprites', 'detect collisions', 'update score'—each piece is easier to solve and test.

cards.front: What is pattern recognition and when would you use it?
cards.back: Finding similarities in problems or data. For example, if you notice several Scratch scripts do the same thing in different sprites, pattern recognition tells you to make a custom block. This saves time and avoids bugs.

cards.front: How does abstraction help with large projects?
cards.back: Abstraction lets you ignore implementation details and think at higher levels. A web developer uses HTML without thinking about how the browser renders it. This mental compression lets you tackle bigger problems.

cards.front: What is a pseudocode and when is it useful?
cards.back: Pseudocode is English-like instructions describing an algorithm, not real code. Write pseudocode first to plan your logic clearly before translating to actual code. It catches logical errors early and is easier to discuss with others.

cards.front: Why should you test edge cases, not just the happy path?
cards.back: The happy path is when everything goes right. Edge cases are unusual inputs: empty lists, negative numbers, single items. Edge cases often break buggy code. Testing them ensures robustness.

cards.front: What is the difference between an algorithm and its implementation?
cards.back: An algorithm is the logic (e.g., binary search steps). Implementation is code in a specific language (Python, C, etc.). The same algorithm can be implemented many ways; good implementations are efficient and clear.

cards.front: How do you know if your algorithm is correct?
cards.back: Verify by hand on small inputs, then test with various cases including edge cases. Trace through your logic step by step. If results match expected output, the algorithm is likely correct.

cards.front: What is computational efficiency and why does it matter?
cards.back: Efficiency is how fast and how much memory an algorithm uses. A slow algorithm might work for 100 items but fail for 1 million. Efficiency becomes crucial as data grows, so choosing the right algorithm early saves time later.

cards.front: Why do programmers prefer clear code over clever code?
cards.back: Clear code is easy to understand, debug, and modify. Clever code impresses no one and wastes time when others (or you later) need to fix it. Readability is more important than showing off.

cards.front: How does debugging differ from testing?
cards.back: Testing checks if code works (pass/fail). Debugging finds why it fails and fixes it. Testing might say 'output is wrong'; debugging finds the cause—off-by-one error, logic mistake, etc.—and solves it.

cards.front: What role does collaboration play in computer science?
cards.back: Most real projects involve teams. Code review catches bugs, discussions clarify design, and version control prevents conflicts. Communication and sharing ideas make better software than isolated genius.

cards.front: What is scalability and why should you think about it early?
cards.back: Scalability means your system works not just for 10 users but 1 million. A naive design might handle small data well but fail when data grows. Thinking about scalability early (choosing efficient algorithms, avoiding memory leaks) prevents costly rewrites later.

cards.front: What is the difference between sequential and parallel processing?
cards.back: Sequential: one task after another. Parallel: multiple tasks simultaneously (on different cores). Most programs are sequential; parallel is complex. For large data (machine learning) or real-time (games), parallelism matters. Modern CPUs have multiple cores; good software uses them.

cards.front: What is an open-source project and why participate in one?
cards.back: Open-source means the source code is publicly available; anyone can view, modify, and contribute. Contributing teaches you real-world coding, collaboration, and version control. It builds your portfolio and connects you to communities. Examples: Linux, Python, web frameworks.

sampleIdeas.name: How Scratch teaches algorithm thinking without syntax stress
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Scratch removes syntax (confusing punctuation and grammar) so learners focus on logic. You don't worry about semicolons or parentheses; you snap blocks together. This is powerful because algorithms are hard enough without fighting the language.

Once you understand algorithm design in Scratch—loops, conditions, decomposition—learning a text language becomes easier. You already know what code should do; you just learn how to write it in Python or C. Many students struggle with C's syntax, but if they've mastered the concepts in Scratch first, syntax is just a tool.

Scratch also enforces good practices naturally. Custom blocks (functions) exist in Scratch, so learners experience why functions matter before memorizing function syntax rules. This bottom-up learning is how CS50 builds strong foundations.

sampleIdeas.name: Why binary and number systems matter in CS
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Understanding binary illuminates how computers actually work. When you see 1010 = 10 in decimal, you grasp that numbers are representations, not magic. This transfers to other encodings: ASCII (letters as numbers), RGB (colors as three numbers), even how computers store negative numbers (two's complement).

Many programmers skip this and regret it. Buffer overflows happen because people don't realize that a byte holds 0–255; they try to store 1000 in it, causing overflow. Integer limits in different languages (32-bit vs 64-bit) confuse people who didn't learn binary. Understanding the hardware-level representation prevents these mistakes.

Furthermore, understanding bases and encoding helps with real tasks: color manipulation in graphics, bit manipulation in low-level code, even cybersecurity (where encoding tricks mask attacks).

sampleIdeas.name: Decomposition as the foundation of scalability
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
A 100-line script is hard to maintain. A 10,000-line script is nearly impossible without decomposition. Decomposition isn't optional—it's how large systems exist.

CS50 emphasizes decomposition early through Scratch's custom blocks and C's functions because this habit, formed early, becomes automatic. When you design a feature, you naturally ask: 'What are the sub-problems?' and 'Can I solve each separately?'

A common mistake is writing one giant function. It works for 50 lines, but at 200 lines it's unmaintainable. By contrast, a program with ten well-designed functions is clearer even if it's 1000 lines total. Each function is testable, reusable, and understandable. This skill transfers to every language and every problem.

sampleIdeas.name: Abstraction as a mental tool, not just a buzzword
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Abstraction lets you work at different levels. When you use the 'move' block in Scratch, you don't think about pixels or the graphics pipeline; you just move. This mental compression is abstraction.

Without abstraction, every program would be overwhelming. A web developer doesn't rewrite the browser engine; they use HTML assuming the browser handles rendering. A game developer doesn't rewrite physics; they use a game engine. Each layer of abstraction lets you focus on the layer above.

The risk of over-abstraction (hiding so much that you can't debug) is real, but the power is undeniable. When you abstract well, complex systems become manageable. CS50 teaches you to abstract ruthlessly, knowing when to stop and peek under the hood when debugging.

sampleIdeas.name: Common mistake: confusing algorithm correctness with efficiency
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
A correct algorithm produces right answers but might be slow. An efficient algorithm is both fast and correct. Beginners often conflate these.

For example, you might write a sorting algorithm that works on 10 items but takes 10 seconds for 10,000 items. It's correct (answers are right) but inefficient (too slow). A better algorithm might also be correct but take 0.1 seconds for 10,000 items.

CS50 teaches Big-O notation to distinguish these. O(n²) algorithms work for small inputs but fail for large ones. When you know your algorithm is O(n²) and your input can be huge, switch to an O(n log n) algorithm. This reasoning happens after you have a correct solution, so solve correctly first, optimize second.

sampleIdeas.name: How pattern recognition prevents repetitive code
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
If you find yourself copying and pasting code three times, stop and make a function. Repeated code is a red flag because: (1) each copy is a potential bug hiding spot, (2) changing the logic means changing it everywhere, and (3) it's hard to read.

Pattern recognition means noticing when you're repeating yourself. In Scratch, if three sprites do nearly the same thing, make a custom block with a parameter. In C, extract repeated code into a function. In any language, DRY (Don't Repeat Yourself) is a core principle.

The mistake beginners make is writing everything straight, then refactoring too late (or not at all). Better to refactor as you go: spot repetition, make a function, test it, move on. This keeps code clean from the start.

sampleIdeas.name: Debugging as a structured skill, not guessing
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Novices debug by changing random things, hoping one works. Experts debug systematically: reproduce the bug consistently, trace the code step-by-step, form a hypothesis, test it.

CS50 teaches debugging early because it's a superpower. In Scratch, you can click code blocks to watch variables change in real-time. This visual tracing is invaluable. In C, you'll use tools like gdb (the debugger), which lets you pause execution and inspect memory.

The method is: (1) Write a minimal test case that triggers the bug, (2) Run it and observe the failure, (3) Look at the code path taken, (4) Find where the code diverges from expected behavior, (5) Fix it, (6) Test again. This methodical approach beats guessing every time and builds the detective skills you'll use for 40 years of programming.

name: Arrays, Strings & Algorithms (CS50)
description: Arrays, command-line arguments, searching, sorting, and Big-O analysis. Weeks 3-4 of CS50 Harvard.

cards.front: What is an array and how do you declare one in C?
cards.back: An array is a contiguous block of memory holding elements of the same type. Declare with type name[size]; like int scores[10]; creates space for 10 integers. Elements are accessed by index: scores[0] is the first.

cards.front: Why do arrays use 0-based indexing instead of 1-based?
cards.back: Arrays are memory blocks; the index is an offset from the start. The first element is at offset 0, the second at offset 1. This design is efficient (direct memory calculation) but trips up beginners used to 1-based lists.

cards.front: What is array bounds checking and what happens if you exceed bounds?
cards.back: C doesn't check if your index is valid. If you access scores[100] on a 10-element array, you read garbage or crash. Modern languages check bounds; C trusts you. This trust means speed but also danger.

cards.front: How do you pass an array to a function in C?
cards.back: Arrays decay to pointers in function calls. void printArray(int arr[], int size); receives arr as a pointer to the first element. The size parameter is necessary because the function can't deduce array length from the pointer alone.

cards.front: Why must you pass array size as a separate parameter?
cards.back: When you pass an array, you're really passing a pointer to its first element. The function has no way to know how many elements follow. If you don't pass size, the function might read past the actual array into garbage memory.

cards.front: What is a string in C and how is it different from a character array?
cards.back: A string is an array of characters ending with a null terminator (\0). "hello" is ['h','e','l','l','o','\0'] in memory. The \0 signals the end, so functions know when to stop reading.

cards.front: How does string.h help with string manipulation?
cards.back: string.h provides functions like strlen() (length), strcpy() (copy), strcat() (concatenate), strcmp() (compare), and strstr() (search). Using them avoids reinventing the wheel and common bugs.

cards.front: Why is strlen() not the array size in C?
cards.back: strlen(s) counts characters until \0; it doesn't know the memory allocated for s. If you allocate char s[100] but only use 5 characters, strlen(s) is 5, not 100. Confusing allocation with length is a common bug.

cards.front: What is argc and argv when a program has command-line arguments?
cards.back: argc is the argument count (number of words on the command line). argv is an array of strings. argv[0] is the program name; argv[1], argv[2], etc. are arguments. For ./greet Alice Bob, argc = 3, argv = ["./greet", "Alice", "Bob"].

cards.front: How do you iterate through argv to access all command-line arguments?
cards.back: Use a loop: for (int i = 0; i < argc; i++) { printf("%s\n", argv[i]); }. This prints each argument. Remember argv[0] is the program name, so arguments start at argv[1].

cards.front: What is linear search and when is it appropriate?
cards.back: Linear search checks each element until finding the target. Best case: O(1) (found first). Worst case: O(n) (not found, checked all). Use it on small or unsorted data. For large sorted data, use binary search.

cards.front: What is binary search and what requirement must data meet?
cards.back: Binary search divides the search space in half each time. If the middle element is too big, search the left half; if too small, search the right half. This works only on sorted data. Time: O(log n), much faster than linear for large data.

cards.front: Why is binary search faster than linear search for large arrays?
cards.back: Linear search might check all n elements; binary search checks at most log n. For 1 million items, linear worst case is 1 million checks; binary is about 20. For 1 billion, linear is 1 billion, binary is about 30.

cards.front: When should you use linear search over binary search despite binary being faster?
cards.back: Use linear search if data is unsorted (sorting first might be slower), if the array is small (overhead of binary search not worth it), or if you need to find all matches (linear naturally does this). Choose based on data and problem, not just Big-O.

cards.front: What is bubble sort and how does it work?
cards.back: Bubble sort repeatedly steps through the array, swapping adjacent elements if they're out of order. Each pass bubbles the largest unsorted element to its place. Time: O(n²). It's simple but slow; rarely used in practice.

cards.front: What is selection sort and how does it compare to bubble sort?
cards.back: Selection sort finds the smallest element and moves it to position 0, then finds the smallest in the remaining and moves it to position 1, etc. Time: also O(n²), but fewer swaps than bubble sort. Still slow for large data.

cards.front: What is merge sort and why is it preferred over bubble/selection sort?
cards.back: Merge sort divides the array in half, recursively sorts each half, then merges them back. Time: O(n log n). Faster than O(n²) sorts for large data. Drawback: uses extra space for the merge. It's a practical choice for general sorting.

cards.front: What does Big-O notation describe about an algorithm?
cards.back: Big-O describes worst-case time complexity: how runtime grows as input size grows. O(n) is linear (runtime proportional to n), O(n²) is quadratic (runtime proportional to n²). Ignore constants: O(2n) and O(n) are both written O(n).

cards.front: What is the difference between Big-O, Big-Omega, and Big-Theta?
cards.back: Big-O is upper bound (worst case). Big-Omega (Ω) is lower bound (best case). Big-Theta (Θ) is tight bound (best and worst are the same). For example, linear search is O(n) worst, Ω(1) best, no Θ because they differ.

cards.front: How do you compare O(n), O(n log n), and O(n²) on large inputs?
cards.back: For n = 1000: O(n) = 1000, O(n log n) ≈ 10,000, O(n²) = 1,000,000. For n = 10,000: O(n) = 10,000, O(n log n) ≈ 130,000, O(n²) = 100,000,000. As n grows, gaps widen exponentially.

cards.front: What is O(1) time and can you give an example?
cards.back: O(1) means constant time: runtime doesn't grow with input size. Accessing an array element by index (arr[5]) is O(1): the computer just calculates the address and fetches. Hash table lookups are O(1) on average.

cards.front: What is O(log n) time and where does it appear?
cards.back: O(log n) means runtime grows logarithmically with input size. Binary search is O(log n): each iteration halves the problem. For n = 1,000,000, log n ≈ 20. Logarithmic algorithms are very efficient.

cards.front: Why is sorting often O(n log n) and not faster?
cards.back: The best comparison-based sorts (like merge sort) prove to be O(n log n) theoretically. You can't do better if you only compare elements because you need at least n log n comparisons to order n items. Non-comparison sorts (like counting sort) can be O(n) for special cases.

cards.front: What is the notation O(2^n) and what problem does it describe?
cards.back: O(2^n) is exponential time: doubling the input roughly squares the runtime. It's intractable for large inputs. For n = 50, 2^n ≈ 1 quadrillion—practically impossible. Many NP-hard problems (traveling salesman, subset sum) are O(2^n).

cards.front: What is a stable sort and why might it matter?
cards.back: A stable sort preserves the relative order of equal elements. If two students have the same grade, a stable sort by grade keeps their original order. Merge sort is stable; selection sort is not. Stability matters when sorting by multiple criteria.

cards.front: What is in-place sorting and why does it matter in practice?
cards.back: In-place sorts use O(1) extra space (only a few variables), like bubble sort and selection sort. Non-in-place sorts (like merge sort) use O(n) extra space. For huge datasets, in-place sorts save memory, though they might be slower.

cards.front: How do you analyze the time complexity of your own algorithm?
cards.back: Count the loops: a single for loop over n items is O(n). Two nested loops are O(n²). A loop that halves input each iteration is O(log n). A loop that divides then recursively processes each half is O(n log n) (if merging takes O(n)).

cards.front: What is a common mistake when analyzing Big-O?
cards.back: Ignoring constants and lower-order terms: O(2n + 5) is O(n). Confusing different inputs: O(n*m) for two arrays of sizes n and m is different from O(n²). Mistaking best-case for Big-O: binary search on sorted data is O(log n), not O(1).

cards.front: Why do you need to understand sorting algorithms if sort() functions exist?
cards.back: Understanding algorithms teaches problem-solving and trade-offs. Sorting exists in libraries, but knowing O(n log n) vs O(n²) helps you choose wisely. Moreover, many problems require custom sorting (different comparison rules), and understanding the principles lets you adapt algorithms.

cards.front: What is a comparison-based sort and what are the alternatives?
cards.back: Comparison-based sorts (bubble, selection, merge, quicksort) decide order by comparing elements. Non-comparison sorts (counting sort, radix sort) don't compare; they use properties of the data (e.g., if items are small integers 0–100). Non-comparison sorts can be O(n) but require special conditions.

cards.front: How does command-line argument parsing help real programs?
cards.back: Programs take arguments for flexibility without recompiling. ./convert 100 converts 100 units, ./search data.txt apple searches a file. This is how Unix tools work. Understanding argc/argv lets you build tools that integrate into workflows.

sampleIdeas.name: Why array bounds checking is deferred to you in C
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
C trusts the programmer; it doesn't check if arr[100] is valid on a 10-element array. You'll read garbage memory, crash, or worse, write data that corrupts other variables. This seems reckless, but it's by design.

Bounds checking costs CPU time and memory overhead. C prioritizes speed; if you want safety, use a language that checks. Learning to manage memory manually teaches discipline. You develop a habit of thinking: 'Is this index valid?' before accessing arrays.

Buffer overflows, one of the most common security vulnerabilities, exploit unchecked array access. Understanding this danger early—by experiencing segfaults firsthand—is valuable. You learn to validate inputs, use assert() for debugging, and keep arrays sized generously.

sampleIdeas.name: Strings as arrays and the null terminator trap
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
In C, strings are just char arrays ending with \0. This design saves memory (no separate length field) and integrates naturally with arrays. But it's a trap: forget the null terminator, and functions overflow memory.

For example, char s[5]; strcpy(s, "hello"); is a buffer overflow: "hello" needs 6 bytes (including \0), but s is only 5 bytes. Safer alternatives: char s[6]; or use strncpy(s, "hello", 5);.

Modern languages store length separately, avoiding this. But C teaches you the cost of memory efficiency. Every abstraction trades something (safety, speed, memory). Understanding these trade-offs makes you a better designer.

sampleIdeas.name: Why binary search requires sorted data and the consequences
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Binary search halves the search space each iteration by comparing the middle element. If the data isn't sorted, 'go left if smaller' might skip the target. For example, searching for 7 in [3, 7, 1, 9] fails because 7 is in the middle but 7 >= 7, so you don't check the middle.

This constraint means: if you'll do many searches, sort once (O(n log n)) then search many times (O(log n) each). If you'll search only once, linear search (O(n)) might be faster than sorting then searching. Problem-solving requires weighing options, not blindly choosing the 'fastest' algorithm.

A practical example: a database with 1 million records. You'll search thousands of times, so indexing (sorting/structuring) pays off. A list you'll search once? Skip sorting.

sampleIdeas.name: How Big-O hides constants and the real-world impact
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
O(n) and O(2n) both simplify to O(n), but 2n is twice as slow. For small n, constants dominate: O(2n) might be faster than O(n log n). Big-O describes how algorithms scale, not their absolute speed.

For example, insertion sort is O(n²) but has small constants; for n < 50, it's faster than merge sort's O(n log n). Real systems tune based on data size: sorting algorithms choose insertion sort for small subarrays, merge sort for large ones.

Another trap: O(n) algorithms with huge constants (like n ∗ 1,000,000) are slower than O(n log n) for reasonable data sizes. Big-O is a heuristic, not gospel. Measure actual performance when it matters.

sampleIdeas.name: Merge sort as a practical algorithm and its trade-offs
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Merge sort is O(n log n) always—best, average, worst. It's stable and parallelizable. But it uses O(n) extra space for merging, and has higher constants than quicksort. In practice, many languages use Timsort (hybrid of merge and insertion sort) for its practical speed and stability.

Merge sort teaches divide-and-conquer: break problems recursively, solve subproblems, combine solutions. This pattern applies far beyond sorting: finding the closest pair of points, multiplying large numbers (Karatsuba), and even parsing (merging parse trees).

Understanding merge sort prepares you for advanced algorithms that use the same strategy.

sampleIdeas.name: Command-line arguments and program flexibility
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Programs that require user input can ask during execution or accept arguments. Arguments let programs integrate into scripts and pipelines. ./greet Alice is more flexible than running ./greet and typing "Alice" when prompted.

Unix philosophy: small tools that do one thing well and can be chained together. grep searches; sort orders; cat concatenates. Each accepts input from the command line or standard input, making them composable.

Understanding argc/argv lets you write flexible tools. It's not just CS50; it's how real systems work. Shell scripts, automation, and CI/CD pipelines depend on programs that accept arguments.

sampleIdeas.name: The practical importance of choosing the right algorithm
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Choosing bubble sort over merge sort for 1 million items means 10,000x slower performance. That's not optimization; it's negligence. Conversely, optimizing a O(log n) algorithm from 20 operations to 10 is pointless—choose the right algorithm first.

CS50 emphasizes this: good algorithmic thinking beats clever coding. A student who chooses O(n log n) from the start outperforms one who optimizes O(n²) endlessly. This principle scales: architectural decisions (choosing the right data structure) matter more than microoptimizations.

Practical wisdom: understand algorithms, profile your code (measure real performance), optimize the bottlenecks. Most code is fast enough; focus on the 10% that matters.

sampleIdeas.name: Analyzing custom algorithms using Big-O reasoning
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Not all algorithms are named (bubble sort, merge sort). You'll write custom loops: maybe searching a 2D array, filtering a list, or updating structures. Analyzing them requires the same thinking: count loop nesting and recursive depth.

Examples: (1) for (int i = 0; i < n; i++) for (int j = 0; j < n; j++) is O(n²). (2) A function that halves its input recursively and processes it is O(n log n) (not O(2^n); exponential is different—each call branches into 2 or more subproblems). (3) A binary search in a sorted 2D array is O(n log m) where n and m are dimensions.

Developing this intuition takes practice. Trace small examples by hand, count operations, estimate growth. Over time, you'll spot O(n log n) patterns instantly.

name: C Programming Basics (CS50)
description: Data types, variables, operators, I/O, conditionals, loops, and functions in C. Weeks 1-2 of CS50 Harvard.

cards.front: Why does CS50 start with C instead of an easier language?
cards.back: C is close to how computers actually work (memory, pointers, compilation). Learning C first makes higher-level languages trivial by comparison. You understand what's happening under the hood, not just using abstractions.

cards.front: What is a data type and why do you specify them in C?
cards.back: A data type tells the compiler how to interpret bytes in memory and how much space to reserve. An int uses 4 bytes, a char uses 1 byte. Without types, the compiler wouldn't know if 65 means the number 65 or the character 'A'.

cards.front: What is the int data type and what range can it hold?
cards.back: An int is a 32-bit signed integer, typically storing values from -2,147,483,648 to 2,147,483,647. It's the default for counting and arithmetic. Larger numbers need long; fractional numbers need float or double.

cards.front: What is the float data type and when do you use it over int?
cards.back: float stores decimal numbers (like 3.14 or -0.5) using 32 bits. Use it for measurements, percentages, or any non-integer math. Note: floats have precision limits; for currency, use integers (cents) or special libraries.

cards.front: Why does C have a char type separate from int?
cards.back: A char is a single character (1 byte), stored as its ASCII number. In C, 'A' and 65 are interchangeable because char is just a tiny int. This design is memory-efficient and useful for strings, which are arrays of chars.

cards.front: What is a string in C and how is it stored?
cards.back: A string is a sequence of characters ending with a null terminator (\0). So "hello" is stored as 5 characters plus \0 in 6 bytes. The null terminator tells functions when the string ends, so they don't read garbage memory.

cards.front: What is the bool data type and how do you use it?
cards.back: bool (requires #include <stdbool.h>) stores true or false. Use it for flags and conditions. In C without stdbool.h, 0 is false and any non-zero is true, but the bool type makes intent clear.

cards.front: How do you declare a variable in C and why is placement important?
cards.back: Declare with type name, like int x; or float pi = 3.14;. In C89, all declarations must come before code in a block. In C99+, declare anywhere. Best practice: declare near where you use it, as it keeps scope tight.

cards.front: What does printf do and what are format codes?
cards.back: printf(format, values) prints formatted output. Format codes like %d (int), %f (float), %s (string), %c (char) tell printf how to interpret values. For example, printf("%d\n", 42) prints '42' followed by a newline.

cards.front: What is the difference between %d and %s in printf?
cards.back: %d interprets the argument as an integer and prints its decimal value. %s interprets it as a pointer to a string and prints all characters until the null terminator. Using the wrong code prints garbage or crashes.

cards.front: How do you get input from the user in C without cs50.h?
cards.back: Use scanf("%d", &x) to read an int into x. The & means 'address of x' (we'll cover pointers later). For strings: char s[50]; scanf("%49s", s);. Strings don't use & because array names are already addresses.

cards.front: Why does CS50 provide cs50.h and what functions does it offer?
cards.back: cs50.h wraps scanf and other functions to make input simple: get_int(), get_string(), get_float() handle error-checking and memory automatically. It's educational because it hides low-level details so students focus on logic, not input plumbing.

cards.front: How do you compare values in C using ==, !=, <, >, <=, >=?
cards.back: These operators return true (1) or false (0). Use == for equality, != for inequality. Note: = assigns, == compares. A common bug is if (x = 5) instead of if (x == 5), which assigns instead of comparing.

cards.front: What is the difference between = and == in an if statement?
cards.back: = assigns a value (x = 5 sets x to 5). == compares (if x == 5 checks if x is 5). In if statements, = will assign 5 to x, then check if x is truthy (non-zero), likely succeeding when you meant to check equality.

cards.front: How do logical operators (&&, ||, !) work in conditionals?
cards.back: && means AND (both must be true). || means OR (at least one must be true). ! means NOT (reverses true/false). Example: if (age >= 18 && hasLicense) means 'if adult AND licensed'; if (x == 0 || y == 0) means 'if x or y is zero'.

cards.front: What is a switch statement and when is it better than multiple if statements?
cards.back: switch compares a value against multiple cases: switch (grade) { case 'A': ... break; case 'B': ... break; }. Use it when one variable has many specific values. It's cleaner than 10 if-else statements.

cards.front: Why do you need break in switch cases?
cards.back: break exits the switch. Without it, execution 'falls through' to the next case, executing unintended code. For example, case 'A': printf("Excellent"); without break will also run case 'B'.

cards.front: What is a for loop and how does it differ from while?
cards.back: for (init; condition; increment) is compact: for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) runs 10 times. while (condition) is flexible and runs as long as condition is true. Use for when iterations are known; use while when the exit condition is less predictable.

cards.front: How do you write an infinite loop intentionally and why?
cards.back: while (true) or for (;;) creates an infinite loop. Use it for programs that run continuously (servers, games) or when you'll break out based on input. Break out with break or return, or exit with exit(0).

cards.front: What is a do-while loop and when do you use it?
cards.back: do-while runs the loop body once, then checks the condition. do { ... } while (condition);. Use it when you must do something at least once, like a menu: ask user, check if valid, ask again if not.

cards.front: How do scope and variable lifetime work in C?
cards.back: A variable declared in a block { } lives only in that block. A for loop's int i lives only in the loop. Global variables (outside functions) live for the program's lifetime. Declaring variables in the smallest scope keeps code clean and avoids conflicts.

cards.front: What is a function declaration and why separate it from implementation?
cards.back: A declaration tells the compiler a function exists: int add(int a, int b);. The implementation (definition) contains the body. Declare at the top; define at the bottom. This lets main() call add() even though add() is defined below.

cards.front: What is the return type of a function and what does it mean?
cards.back: The return type (int, float, void) specifies what the function gives back. int add(int a, int b) returns an int. void means the function returns nothing. Call it like int result = add(2, 3); only if the return type isn't void.

cards.front: How do parameters and arguments differ in function definitions?
cards.back: Parameters are the names in the function definition: int add(int a, int b). Arguments are the values passed when calling: add(2, 3). Parameters are the 'slots'; arguments are the 'values you put in'.

cards.front: What happens to arguments when you pass them to a function in C?
cards.back: C uses pass-by-value: a copy of the argument is made and passed. Changes to the parameter inside the function don't affect the original variable outside. To modify a variable, use a pointer (we'll cover this later).

cards.front: Why do some functions return void and how do you call them?
cards.back: void means the function does something but returns nothing. Example: void printSum(int a, int b) { printf("%d\n", a + b); }. Call it without assigning: printSum(2, 3);.

cards.front: What is the difference between declaring variables in main() vs globally?
cards.back: Main-declared variables are local; they're created when main starts and destroyed when it ends. Global variables exist for the program's entire run. Locals are safer (fewer name conflicts); globals are risky but sometimes necessary.

cards.front: Why does main() return int and what does return 0; mean?
cards.back: main() returns an int that tells the operating system if the program succeeded. return 0; means success; any non-zero value indicates an error. The OS uses this to know if the program ran correctly.

cards.front: What is a common off-by-one error and how do you avoid it?
cards.back: Loops often use i < n instead of i <= n, or vice versa. Example: for (int i = 0; i < 10; i++) runs 10 times (0–9). For (int i = 0; i <= 10; i++) runs 11 times (0–10). Count items carefully and use < for 0-indexing.

cards.front: How do you compile a C program and why does the process matter?
cards.back: Use clang filename.c -o filename (or gcc). The compiler translates C to machine code, catching syntax errors. If compilation fails, you have syntax errors; if it succeeds but runs wrong, you have logic errors. Compilation is the first debugging step.

cards.front: What are common compilation errors and how do you fix them?
cards.back: 'undeclared identifier' means you used a variable without declaring it. 'conflicting types' means you declared a function twice with different signatures. 'missing semicolon' is obvious. Read error messages carefully; they say which line is wrong.

cards.front: Why is it important to test with different inputs when you code?
cards.back: Code might work for happy inputs (5, 10) but fail for edge cases (0, negative, 1). Test boundaries: zero, negative numbers, very large numbers, empty strings. This catches logic errors a single test won't reveal.

cards.front: What is the difference between assignment (=) and equality (==)?
cards.back: = stores a value in a variable (x = 5). == checks if two values are equal (if x == 5). Confusing them is a classic bug: if (x = 5) always succeeds (assigns 5, then checks if x is truthy).

sampleIdeas.name: Why C forces you to think about types and memory
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
In Python, you write x = 5 and don't worry about memory. In C, you must declare int x = 5, thinking about what int means (32 bits, signed). This seems annoying, but it's intentional.

Forcing type declarations makes you think early. What range do I need? Will negative numbers appear? Do I need decimals? These questions matter in real systems where memory is limited or precision matters. A financial system storing cents as integers is safer than floats because floats can't represent 0.1 exactly.

C makes these trade-offs visible. You see that a char is 1 byte, an int is 4, a double is 8. This teaches you to design efficiently. In Python, you never think about it; in C, you can't ignore it.

sampleIdeas.name: How printf format codes prevent hidden bugs
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
printf("%d", 3.14) prints wrong because 3.14 is a float but %d expects an int. The compiler can't always catch this at compile time if you pass variables. Using the correct format code is critical.

Common mistakes: printing a pointer with %d (shows garbage), printing an int with %s (reads random memory as a string and crashes), printing a float with %d (loses decimals silently). Many languages handle this automatically; C makes you explicit, which teaches precision.

Better yet, modern compilers warn about mismatched format codes if you enable warnings (-Wall). Pay attention to those warnings—they catch real bugs before runtime.

sampleIdeas.name: The = vs == mistake and why it's so common
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Beginners write if (x = 5) and wonder why the condition always succeeds. The problem: = assigns (sets x to 5), then the if checks if x is non-zero (which it is, so true). They meant == to compare.

This happens because both look similar. Some languages (like Python) forbid = in conditions, forcing ==. C doesn't, so you can introduce bugs silently. The fix: enable compiler warnings (-Wall) and read them. Many compilers warn about assignment in conditionals.

Another fix: develop a habit of writing if (5 == x) instead, so if you accidentally write if (5 = x), the compiler errors (can't assign to a literal). This style is odd but safe.

sampleIdeas.name: Why function declarations are crucial in C
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
In C, you must declare a function before calling it. If you write main() but define add() after main(), the code won't compile unless you declare add() beforehand. This seems tedious, but it serves a purpose.

Declaring first forces you to plan your function interfaces before writing details. You think: what inputs do I need? What should I return? This discipline improves design. Moreover, declarations let the compiler check that calls match signatures, catching type errors early.

Proto-tip: put all function declarations at the top of your file, then implementations below. Or put implementations in separate .c files with a .h header file declaring them. This scales well for large projects.

sampleIdeas.name: Null-terminated strings as a design pattern
sampleIdeas.textDescription:
Strings in C end with \0 (null terminator), a special character marking the end. This design is elegant but easy to mess up. If you forget \0, functions like strlen() or printf("%s") read past the actual string into garbage memory, causing crashes or revealing secrets.

Why null-terminate? Because C has no 'length' data stored with a string. Functions don't know where the string ends except by finding \0. This saves memory (no length field) but requires discipline.
